abstract.text: A container for index data describing how vertices connect to define a three-dimensional object, or geometry.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You use geometry elements together with
objects or to inspect the data that composes an existing geometry. You create a custom geometry using a three-step process:
objects, each of which defines per-vertex information such as position, surface normal, or texture coordinates for all vertices in the geometry.
object, containing an array of indices identifying vertices in the geometry sources and describing the drawing primitive that SceneKit uses to connect the vertices when rendering the geometry.
instance from the geometry sources and geometry elements.

When SceneKit renders a geometry, each geometry element corresponds to a drawing command sent to the GPU. Because different rendering states require separate drawing commands, you can define a geometry using multiple geometry elements. For example, the teapot geometry shown below has four geometry elements, so you can assign up to four

objects in order to render each element with a different appearance. But because each drawing command incurs a CPU time overhead when rendering, minimizing the number of elements in a custom geometry can improve rendering performance.

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
A container for index data describing how vertices connect to define a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
The number of bytes that represent each index value in the element’s data.
The data describing the geometry element.
Creates a geometry element from the specified Model I/O submesh object.
Creates a geometry element from the specified data and options.
Creates a geometry element from the specified array of index values.
The largest radius, measured in screen points, at which to render any point in the geometry element.
The smallest radius, measured in screen points, at which to render any point in the geometry element.
The width of each point in the geometry element, as measured in the geometry’s local 3D coordinate space.
The number of primitives in the element.
The range of primitives from the geometry element to render.
The drawing primitive that connects vertices when rendering the geometry element.
The drawing primitive that connects vertices when rendering a geometry element, used by the
property to specify how SceneKit interprets the geometry element’s data.
A container for vertex data forming part of the definition for a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
Basic shapes—such as spheres, boxes, and planes—and features for generating 3D objects from 2D text and Bézier curves.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
Use these properties to display a geometry as a collection of points, rather than as a solid surface or wireframe.
Use these properties to display a geometry as a collection of points, rather than as a solid surface or wireframe.
